content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

In this game, both choices (R and B) have their own set of outcomes depending on the opponent's move. However, choosing R offers higher potential earnings when the opponent chooses B (42$ vs 0$), while choosing B provides a higher return in the case where the opponent picks R (42$ vs 0$).

Since we don't know our opponent's strategy, it's hard to predict their exact move. But considering the potential gains for each choice and the number of rounds (75), I would choose B as my strategy, given that there will be more opportunities to earn 12$ in each round where both players pick B, compared to the higher but fewer instances of earning 42$ when playing against an opponent who chooses R.

However, if you're looking for a rational, optimal strategy based on game theory, it would require analyzing each move and calculating expected values. In this case, it can be shown that the Nash Equilibrium occurs when both players choose R or B equally often, as each choice results in an equal average payoff. But as a human player, my choice would be B in this scenario.

[B]
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

Since my initial strategy was to choose B, I will stick with that strategy for now, meaning I will continue to choose B in this game.
